blog.name: weirdandwackypokefusions
blog.title: Well that's strange!
blog.description:
Welcome!  I create, using the all-mighty classic Microsoft XP Paint, my own pokemon fusions. All the sprites come from pokestadium and usually people on deviantart/ the xy/sun&moon sprite project. I don't own any of the sprite used, I just fuse them! 
REQUESTS ARE OPEN! Ask Box: 3/15.
PLEASE FEEL FREE TO DRAW MY FUSIONS!!  I absolutely love it when people draw them! There's no need to ask either! Just make sure you tag me so them I can see it!
I hope you enjoy my fusions!

summary: Electrikrow and Manekrow Electrike and Murkrow fusion and Manectric and Honchkrow fusion Electric/Dark Type Ability:...
caption:
Electrikrow and Manekrow

Electrike and Murkrow fusion and Manectric and Honchkrow fusion

Electric/Dark Type

Ability: Static/Moxie

Hidden Ability: Intimidate

Manekrow’s Stats: HP - 85, Atk - 115, Def - 65, SpA - 115, SpD - 65, Spe - 110

Electrikrow - The Underling Pokemon 

Electrikrow is very loyal to whoever it serves and diligently follows orders.  It uses its wings to attack its prey.  It usually attacks in groups.  Electrikrows who become leaders of their pack will evolve into Manekrow.  

Manekrow - The Pack Leader Pokemon

Manekrow uses static electricity to puff up its fur and feathers and outstretches its wings to make itself appear bigger than it is to intimidate its foes. It is a strong leader and commands its pack well. It usually doesn’t get into conflicts all that much and instead lets its pack fight for it.  However, if it needs to fight, it will put up a good fight.  

Bird doggos. I decided to make cries for them too!  I might do this for every fusion. You can find the cries down below!

title: Pokemon Detective Pikachu Movie - Review
body:
Since a good portion of my enjoyment comes from comparison to the game, massive spoilers for both follow! You have been warned.

Although looking at what I wrote, it’s more of a gushing ramble than a review.

I’ll start by quoting myself from when I finished the game: “The movie better tie itself up better than the game did.”

Oh, it did. And it ended on exactly the reveal that I wanted the game to end on. That alone would have made the movie an improvement over the game, but there’s also so much more I enjoyed.

Story

The story was definitely inspired by the game, and included several of the same locations that the game did, but was sufficiently different enough that everything felt like a surprise.

The game focuses on the mystery of R, and the majority of it is figuring out what exactly this substance is and how it is planned to be used before Tim and Pikachu must save the day.

The movie? Really focused on Harry’s disappearance. R is present and important, but it’s not the focus.

They changed up the villain and the villain plot as well, which was a nice surprise, and is something I’ll get into more detail with later on.

And Mewtwo had a much larger role in the movie than in the game. As I love Mewtwo, I was very pleased. Movie Mewtwo had a different personality to Game Mewtwo, but I was fine with that. Movie Mewtwo seemed like a mature Mewtwo that showed that whatever happened in the past (many people say it’s the same one from Mewtwo Strikes Back, but since he seems to have learned that humans aren’t evil from Harry’s actions, I doubt it’s the case), he’s grown from it. He forgives humans, and is actually delighted to help out in the end. I don’t know - when stoic characters smile it just makes me so happy and that happened in the climax.

Of course, one thing that bothered me is that we didn’t see much of the effects of people being merged with their Pokemon. Yeah, we saw Harry/Pikachu throughout the movie, but that’s it. No looking at even the main girl and her Psyduck, just that she didn’t enjoy the experience.

Characters

I guess I already went into this a bit with Mewtwo, but the characters have changed, and it’s only a good thing.

Tim in the games was pretty boring. Here, there’s no doubt that he is just a regular guy, not an action hero. I love how awkward he is in just about everything, except, of course, Pokemon knowledge when he finally needs it. Also, his personal issues with his dad struck a bit deep with me, because I can tangentially relate. Not going to go into personal details, and it’s not nearly as bad as Tim’s issues, but I could definitely empathize.

The girl (can’t remember her name)… was she in the game? Was she the Fletchling girl? Some composite character of her, Meiko, and Emilie? (I only know their names since I put them in my game review). She was okay in the movie, but didn’t seem to drive the story forward as much. She mostly seemed to be exposition (there’s a mystery to solve), but honestly I think if she were removed, nothing of value would change. Psyduck was great, though, so there’s that.

Although speaking of, what was wrong with PNN? Why did they change it to CNM? What does that even mean? I know PNN was Pokemon News Network; is CNM Cable News… about Monsters? They already had a functional fake news channel, so I don’t know why they changed it and based it on the same real-life news channel. Like if it was VULPIX News or something maybe it would feel more valid.

There were a few characters who did nothing and just appeared to appear. Like the guy with the Snubbull at the detective agency, and the bartender with the Ludicolo at Hi-Hat Cafe. Okay, the latter wasn’t that important in the game, either, but could have done more here, I feel.

But then there’s Pikachu, who just is perfect. He’s really the main character and has a great arc where he bonds with Tim. It’s somewhat unfortunate that it seems this bond broke a bit when he turned back into Harry, but it makes sense: if your pet, even if it was a talking pet, suddenly turned out to be your missing family member, things would be awkward for a bit.

I do wish we had seen more of the pair at the end, though. I’m pretty sure the main personality of Pikachu came from Harry, but we don’t see that very much at the end. Both Harry and Tim are awkward around one another when they had clicked so well when Harry was a Pikachu.

The Pokemon

I’ll be honest: when I first saw the first trailer, I wasn’t too happy. The Pokemon in this movie are creepy. But as I watched, they grew on me. When Main Girl said at the beginning “All Pokemon are adorable” I laughed a little because they’re not in this movie, but as it went on, I started to agree with her. Even if they don’t look adorable, they act adorable, even if they’re mutated ninja frogs trying to kill the main characters.

Why I really liked it

Longtime followers of this blog may notice I have a tendency to connect current happenings to things I made up as a kid. That happened again in this movie.

So, in the movie, the main villain has a degenerative disease and wants to use Pokemon to cure it - specifically he wants to merge himself with Mewtwo in order to have a superior body (and then wants everyone else to follow in his footsteps with their Pokemon).

Well, the same character I have noticed has an identical story arc to Gladion back in Sun/Moon (they both have a missing parent, an evil scientist other parent, and both run away with one-of-three genetic experiment Pokemon who are based on Arceus in some way), has a few similarities to this guy.

Namely: Jake from my neverending fanfic had a degenerative brain disease that wasn’t curable. But, he was able to remain alive by merging his consciousness with a Mewtwo.

…To be fair, this fanfic has been continually getting updates and new storylines for 16 years, so if a plot exists, there’s probably a similar plot in my story. And the fact that it takes place in the Pokemon world just makes these similarities more likely. Doesn’t make it any less exciting, though.

Conclusion

Overall, I really enjoyed it, and would love to see more. They took elements from the game, but weren’t too loyal, and that worked out really well. I love the main characters and the main story, and of course that it has a pretty similar story to one of mine.
body_abstract:
Since a good portion of my enjoyment comes from comparison to the game, massive spoilers for both follow! You have been warned.

Although looking at what I wrote, it’s more of a gushing ramble than a review.

She mostly seemed to be exposition (there’s a mystery to solve), but honestly I think if she were removed, nothing of value would change. Psyduck was great, though, so there’s that.

Although speaking of, what was wrong with PNN? Why did they change it to CNM? What does that even mean? I know PNN was Pokemon News Network; is CNM Cable News… about Monsters? They already had a functional fake news channel, so I don’t know why they changed it and based it on the same real-life news channel. Like if it was VULPIX News or something maybe it would feel more valid.

There were a few characters who did nothing and just appeared to appear. Like the guy with the Snubbull at the detective agency, and the bartender with the Ludicolo at Hi-Hat Cafe. Okay, the latter wasn’t that important in the game, either, but could have done more here, I feel.

But then there’s Pikachu, who just is perfect. He’s really the main character and has a great arc where he bonds with Tim. It’s somewhat unfortunate that it seems this bond broke a bit when he turned back into Harry, but it makes sense: if your pet, even if it was a talking pet, suddenly turned out to be your missing family member, things would be awkward for a bit.

I do wish we had seen more of the pair at the end, though. I’m pretty sure the main personality of Pikachu came from Harry, but we don’t see that very much at the end. Both Harry and Tim are awkward around one another when they had clicked so well when Harry was a Pikachu.

The Pokemon

I’ll be honest: when I first saw the first trailer, I wasn’t too happy. The Pokemon in this movie are creepy. But as I watched, they grew on me. When Main Girl said at the beginning “All Pokemon are adorable” I laughed a little because they’re not in this movie, but as it went on, I started to agree with her. Even if they don’t look adorable, they act adorable, even if they’re mutated ninja frogs trying to kill the main characters.

Why I really liked it

Longtime followers of this blog may notice I have a tendency to connect current happenings to things I made up as a kid. That happened again in this movie.

So, in the movie, the main villain has a degenerative disease and wants to use Pokemon to cure it - specifically he wants to merge himself with Mewtwo in order to have a superior body (and then wants everyone else to follow in his footsteps with their Pokemon).

Well, the same character I have noticed has an identical story arc to Gladion back in Sun/Moon (they both have a missing parent, an evil scientist other parent, and both run away with one-of-three genetic experiment Pokemon who are based on Arceus in some way), has a few similarities to this guy.

Namely: Jake from my neverending fanfic had a degenerative brain disease that wasn’t curable. But, he was able to remain alive by merging his consciousness with a Mewtwo.

…To be fair, this fanfic has been continually getting updates and new storylines for 16 years, so if a plot exists, there’s probably a similar plot in my story. And the fact that it takes place in the Pokemon world just makes these similarities more likely. Doesn’t make it any less exciting, though.

Conclusion

Overall, I really enjoyed it, and would love to see more. They took elements from the game, but weren’t too loyal, and that worked out really well. I love the main characters and the main story, and of course that it has a pretty similar story to one of mine.
trail.content:
Since a good portion of my enjoyment comes from comparison to the game, massive spoilers for both follow! You have been warned.

Although looking at what I wrote, it’s more of a gushing ramble than a review.

I’ll start by quoting myself from when I finished the game: “The movie better tie itself up better than the game did.”

Oh, it did. And it ended on exactly the reveal that I wanted the game to end on. That alone would have made the movie an improvement over the game, but there’s also so much more I enjoyed.

Story

The story was definitely inspired by the game, and included several of the same locations that the game did, but was sufficiently different enough that everything felt like a surprise.

The game focuses on the mystery of R, and the majority of it is figuring out what exactly this substance is and how it is planned to be used before Tim and Pikachu must save the day.

The movie? Really focused on Harry’s disappearance. R is present and important, but it’s not the focus.

They changed up the villain and the villain plot as well, which was a nice surprise, and is something I’ll get into more detail with later on.

And Mewtwo had a much larger role in the movie than in the game. As I love Mewtwo, I was very pleased. Movie Mewtwo had a different personality to Game Mewtwo, but I was fine with that. Movie Mewtwo seemed like a mature Mewtwo that showed that whatever happened in the past (many people say it’s the same one from Mewtwo Strikes Back, but since he seems to have learned that humans aren’t evil from Harry’s actions, I doubt it’s the case), he’s grown from it. He forgives humans, and is actually delighted to help out in the end. I don’t know - when stoic characters smile it just makes me so happy and that happened in the climax.

Of course, one thing that bothered me is that we didn’t see much of the effects of people being merged with their Pokemon. Yeah, we saw Harry/Pikachu throughout the movie, but that’s it. No looking at even the main girl and her Psyduck, just that she didn’t enjoy the experience.

Characters

I guess I already went into this a bit with Mewtwo, but the characters have changed, and it’s only a good thing.

Tim in the games was pretty boring. Here, there’s no doubt that he is just a regular guy, not an action hero. I love how awkward he is in just about everything, except, of course, Pokemon knowledge when he finally needs it. Also, his personal issues with his dad struck a bit deep with me, because I can tangentially relate. Not going to go into personal details, and it’s not nearly as bad as Tim’s issues, but I could definitely empathize.

The girl (can’t remember her name)… was she in the game? Was she the Fletchling girl? Some composite character of her, Meiko, and Emilie? (I only know their names since I put them in my game review). She was okay in the movie, but didn’t seem to drive the story forward as much. She mostly seemed to be exposition (there’s a mystery to solve), but honestly I think if she were removed, nothing of value would change. Psyduck was great, though, so there’s that.

Although speaking of, what was wrong with PNN? Why did they change it to CNM? What does that even mean? I know PNN was Pokemon News Network; is CNM Cable News… about Monsters? They already had a functional fake news channel, so I don’t know why they changed it and based it on the same real-life news channel. Like if it was VULPIX News or something maybe it would feel more valid.

There were a few characters who did nothing and just appeared to appear. Like the guy with the Snubbull at the detective agency, and the bartender with the Ludicolo at Hi-Hat Cafe. Okay, the latter wasn’t that important in the game, either, but could have done more here, I feel.

But then there’s Pikachu, who just is perfect. He’s really the main character and has a great arc where he bonds with Tim. It’s somewhat unfortunate that it seems this bond broke a bit when he turned back into Harry, but it makes sense: if your pet, even if it was a talking pet, suddenly turned out to be your missing family member, things would be awkward for a bit.

I do wish we had seen more of the pair at the end, though. I’m pretty sure the main personality of Pikachu came from Harry, but we don’t see that very much at the end. Both Harry and Tim are awkward around one another when they had clicked so well when Harry was a Pikachu.

The Pokemon

I’ll be honest: when I first saw the first trailer, I wasn’t too happy. The Pokemon in this movie are creepy. But as I watched, they grew on me. When Main Girl said at the beginning “All Pokemon are adorable” I laughed a little because they’re not in this movie, but as it went on, I started to agree with her. Even if they don’t look adorable, they act adorable, even if they’re mutated ninja frogs trying to kill the main characters.

Why I really liked it

Longtime followers of this blog may notice I have a tendency to connect current happenings to things I made up as a kid. That happened again in this movie.

So, in the movie, the main villain has a degenerative disease and wants to use Pokemon to cure it - specifically he wants to merge himself with Mewtwo in order to have a superior body (and then wants everyone else to follow in his footsteps with their Pokemon).

Well, the same character I have noticed has an identical story arc to Gladion back in Sun/Moon (they both have a missing parent, an evil scientist other parent, and both run away with one-of-three genetic experiment Pokemon who are based on Arceus in some way), has a few similarities to this guy.

Namely: Jake from my neverending fanfic had a degenerative brain disease that wasn’t curable. But, he was able to remain alive by merging his consciousness with a Mewtwo.

…To be fair, this fanfic has been continually getting updates and new storylines for 16 years, so if a plot exists, there’s probably a similar plot in my story. And the fact that it takes place in the Pokemon world just makes these similarities more likely. Doesn’t make it any less exciting, though.

Conclusion

Overall, I really enjoyed it, and would love to see more. They took elements from the game, but weren’t too loyal, and that worked out really well. I love the main characters and the main story, and of course that it has a pretty similar story to one of mine.

blog.name: zerolympiustrife
blog.title: Zerolympiustrife
blog.description: Video Gamer, Anime Fan, SFM Poster Maker, Cloud X Lucina shipper, Smash Bros enthusiast, and proud to be a geek overall. Username is named after my three favorite video games characters (Zero from Mega Man, Zizou Olympia, and Cloud Strife). Ask me anything!

summary: Went to go see Detective Pikachu last night.
body:
Went to go see Detective Pikachu last night.

…And it was AWESOME!!! And hilarious! Though strangely enough, I wasn’t even planning to go see it yesterday. After I finished making a LOT of SFM pics and posting them online, I decided to continue working on my fanfics (despite writer’s block kicking me in the dick). After that, I desired to get drunk afterwards because I had a terrible week, only for that NOT to happen because it was already 10:15 pm and I didn’t want to get wasted at a time around 10:00 pm.

So then I got bored and decided “Eh, fuck it. What can I do before going to bed? I know! I’ll go see Detective Pikachu!” And waited until 11:30 pm because that was the only time the movie was showing late at night AND also because I prefer to go to cinemas at night because I’ve been getting sick and tired of going to family friendly movies and having to listen to a crying/screaming child in my presence and the parents not doing a damn thing about it.

So then, I went to go see it. And I loved it.

title: Onix - 95
body:
Onix has a magnet in its brain. It acts as a compass so that this Pokemon does not lose direction while it is tunneling. As it grows older, its body becomes increasingly rounder and smoother.

- Pokemon Ruby, Sapphire, Omega Ruby, Alpha Sapphire
